Muller Champions
Tuition Hike at SC
by Frank Caprio
Univsisity President Steven
Muller, in a roundtable meeting
of Student Council Wednesday
evening, explained that next
year's $800 tuition increase was
necessary because "the costs in
which we expect undergraduates to share are going
up."
Muller began the meeting
with an apology to council, explaining that while he has
"tried each year to meet with
the council before the Trustees
decide on the tuition," it was
impossible this year to schedule
a meeting before the tuition increase was announced at the
February Trustees' meeting.
On a list of schools ranked
by 1985-6 tuition which Muller
presented to council, Hopkins
is shown as the 50th most expensive school among them.

"My guess is we will stay in this
position this year and for the
indefinite future," commented
Muller.
Compared with the 100 other
schools listed, Hopkins' tuition
was just $166 more than the,
average cost of the private institutions. "Out tuition does
not, I think, reflect our quality," added Muller.
The increase should not put
any extra burdens on students
receiving financial aid since the
rise in University aid funds will
be slightly higher than the
change in tuition, according to
Muller.
Justifying the size of the tuition hike, Muller explained,
"After inflation, this represents
a real increase of less than 5
percent." Muller reported that
while tuition over the last

Coalition, Republicans Agree to Debate
by Jon Stempel
The College Republicans and
the JHU Coalition for a Free
South Africa will come face to
face on the issues of University
divestment in a debate sponsored by the House of Commons at 8 p.m. Sunday in the
Listening-Viewing Room.
The debate, which is sponsored by the House of Commons, will feature representatives of two groups whose
debate on the merits and pitfalls
of divestment has culminated in
a Coalition-built shantytown
and a College Republican-built
Soviet gulag appearing opposite
each other on the lower quad.
"Because the House of Commons is an impartial group that
debates political issues," said
House of Commons President
Steve Nicewarner, "we feel that
we would be providing a service

by sponsoring this forum for
debate."
In the debate, each group will
make opening statements, respond to three questions and
rebut its opponent's responses,
and have a chance to make concluding remarks.

Verica Beats Chun By 7 Votes
In Run-Off Elections Tuesday
by Jeff Horn
Chris Verica broke the tie
with Andrew Chun for senior
class president by seven votes in
the run-off elections held on
Tuesday.
Chun said, "I kinda saw it
coming. I had an idea of who
got out to vote and I knew it
was going to be close, but it's
disappointing to lose by such a
close margin."
Verica, according to Paul
Kadri, who spoke to him by
telephone at his hospital in
Pennsylvania, "is really happy
to have won, and wants to give
thanks to those who have sup-

ported him and campaigned for
him."
Kadri said Verica is doing
well and is now on crutches,
which he hopes to trade for a
cane, and is hoping to attend
the FIJI semi-formal this
semester. He wants to "finish
his classes this summer, work
for the class, and sell Blue Jays
for Project Blue Jay," according to Kadri.
Chun concluded, "I didn't
really consider Chris to be my
opponent, I considered it to be
Paul. As he's shown in the past,
he's pretty tough to beat."
The senior class SC
Representatives will be Winston

APRIL 25, 1986

Vaughan, Brad Marks, and
Donald Chang.
One problem with the election did arise. Posters were put
up in the freshman dormitories
against class of 1989 SC

concerning his campaign this

Make the Same Mistake Twice,
Don't Vote for Erick Santos."
The rest of the posters said that

An undergraduate dormitory
resident became the victim of
an armed robbery and attempted
rape in her room on the morning of Sunday, April 20, according to campus security.
A preliminary investigation
of the incident suggests that the
assailant may have entered the
dormitory complex through
unlocked building and dormitory rooms, according to a
statement issued by Associate
Dean of Students Chris
Colombo.
Officer Edward Weichert of
campus security said, "We
found no evidence of forced entry, but that's not so unusual
since the building doors are
often left unlocked or propped
open."
According to Colombo's
statement, the victim described
her attacker as a black male in
his mid-twenties, approximately 5'9" and weighing 150 to 160
pounds. He was described as
having no facial hair and was
wearing a waist length tan
suede jacket, a white t-shirt,
blue jeans, and a tan leather
shoes.
According to Colombo and
Weichert, a review of dormitory security measures is currently underway. Weichert added though,"No committee has
been set up. We're just reviewing present measures."
He also said that security at
the dorms has not been increased
as a result of Sunday's incident.
According to Weichert, "Officers are detailed to the dormitories on a twenty-four hour
basis at night."
Both campus security and the
Baltimore City Police are currently investigating the incident. Anyone who may have
seen the assailant or a car
speeding away from the dorms
on Sunday morning is asked to
contact campus security.

What's Inside
Before a large Homecoming
crowd, the Blue Jays faced
perhaps their best opponent
of the season Saturday—the
Maryland Terrapins. After
trailing by one at the half,
the Terps tied it early in the
third quarter, only to have
the Blue Jays score four
unanswered goals. Hopkins
eventually went on to a 14-9
win. Details, pg. 17.
Richard Chisolm, an instructor in the Writing Seminars
Department, probably won't be teaching a course next year.
For the reason why, see pg. 12.

Eighteen Seniors 'Throated Off'SAC Seal List
by Frank Caprio
The Student Council approved a highly controversial list of
SAC awards recipients at
Wednesday's meeting by a rollcall vote of 7-4-2. The list,
which included only 14 of the
32 names which previously appeared, was revised after council members rejected the
original list which was submitted to them by the SAC Executive Board two weeks ago.
Thoss graduating seniors
who wiT receive the awards include David Ades, Darrell
Cook, Teresa Cook, Michael
DeRosa, James Farina, Charles
Greene III, James Hoff, Jeffrey Lurie, Peter Oehlkers,
Tamara Oki, Karen Raisbeck,
Ethan
Rarick,
Alan
Rebenstock, and James
Sullivan.
Among the seven council
members voting infavor of the
proposed list were Paul Donio,
Alan Rebenstock, Mark
Komisky, Winston Vaughan,
Saurin Shah, Bruce Howard,
and Erick Santos. Ngozi
Osuagwu, Rachel Cohen, Andy Chun, and Brad Marks opposed the list, while Alison Little and Brian Doyle abstained.
After council rejected the
original list, the SAC Executive
Board reopened nominations
and, in response to council
complaints, increased publicity
of the awards. By last Friday at
noon,
SAC
Chairman
Rebenstock had received sixteen additional nominations.
According to Rebenstock,
the SAC Board "started over
with a blank piece of paper"
and began to look at all the
recommendations again. "We
drew up a list with a tighter and
stricter requirement," he explained. "This was because of
a large number of candidates

Kurt Schmoke, the Baltimore
city state's attorney, will address the graduates of the Johns
Hopkins Tutorial Project at the
Spring Graduation Ceremony
at 4:30 Tuesday. April 29 in the
Shriver Hall Auditorium.
The program will begin at
4:30 when the Johns Hopkins
Band will play. Following
Schmoke's speech, over two
hundred elementary school
students from Baltimore who
participated in the Tutorial
Project will receive awards and
diplomas. The children will
finish the ceremony with a
talent show and then go on to
a "cake and punch" reception.
The Tutorial Project, approaching its thirtieth year of
continuous service, provides
personal tutoring of Baltimore
youth by Hopkins students.
The tutors spend four hours a
week with the children in a oneto-one learning experience.
All members of the Hopkins

healthier.
But one enterprising professor has found a new health
hazard on campus.

6/APRIL 25 1986

Four Hopkins Profs Win Guggenheim Awards
by Tom McNamara
Four faculty members at the
Johns Hopkins Institutions
have been presented Guggenheim Fellowship Awards for
1986. Jean Eichelberger Ivey,
Member of the Faculty in Composition and Director of the
Electronic Music Studio at the
Peabody Conservatory; Ronald
Paulson, William D. And
Robin Mayer Professor of the
Humanities and progessor of
English at the Homewood campus; William T. Rowe, associate professor of History,
Homewood; and Alan Walker,
professor of Cell Biology and
Anatomy at the School of
Medicine received the awards.
The fellowships provide funding for specific research projects proposed by the recipients
to the Guggenheim Foundationover a period of one year.
According to the Foundation, "The new Guggenheim
Fellows were appointed on the
basis of unusually distinguished achievement in the past and
exceptional promise for future
accomplishment." In 62 years,
over $116 million in fellowships
have been awarded.
Rowe received a grant to do
research in 18th-century
Chinese history over a period of
one year, spending the first six
months in Baltimore and the
last six in Taiwan. He described the research as primarily
biographical, covering th•
career of Ch'en Hung-mou,
who "was probably the most

STOP
END

influential
official
in
eighteenth-century China," and
served as governor or in the upper levels of administration of
at least twelve of the eighteen
Chinese provinces at different
times.
Ch'en was "an exemplar of
his particular style of government" who tried to understand
local communities and use existing local leaders and grotips
in governing and tried to rule
using preexisting forces, a
theory known as ching-shih,
translated as "statecraft."
Rowe said that part of the
research will be to learn in
detail how this administrator
applied his political ideas to
practical situations in different
areas—political ideas which
were very different from the
traditional Confucian concept
of leadership by example.
A seeming paradox is that
Ch'en was viewed later as both
an exponent of this pragmatic
school of thought, which as remained influential in China
ever since, and as "a great
moralist," according to Rowe.
Ch'en's work on the development of education stressing
cultural values, and his moral
treatises, as well as his letters
and writings on government
have been very influential.
According to Rowe, comparison of the theories and the
actual practices of this official
may help "to draw together the
sub-disciplines of intellectual
history and socio-political
history" of late imperial China.

Paulson's research will be on
"Memorial images in 18-th century English art and literature."
He wil study funerary
monuments, including statues
and architecture as well as written elements such as elegies and
epitaphs. In addition, he will
study images began in the 18th
century and the ways in which
they were broken up and
reconstructed and how people's
interest in these memorials
developed them over time.
Paulson will also be investigating the connections between the different art forms in
this area—he mentioned in his
book Book and Painting that,
"There is a real sense in which
English painting was a branch
of literature rather that art."
One reason for this was that
English literature was more
purely English than art was at
that time, and so was
sometimes more appealing to
English artists than were the
works of foreign painters.
Part of Paulson's research
will involve traveling in
England, in order to study
funerary monuments. The project will also include reading
and analysis of various
memorial writings, and traveling in England in order to study
these monuments. The project
will also include reading and
analyzing various memorial
writings.
Walker, at the medical
school, will be studying
"growth and sexual dimorphism in ancient hominoids."

Hominoids, he explained, include both apes and humans.
The study will center on two
groups of fossil remains, one of
ape-like animals approximately 18 million years old, and the
other of homo erectus, a
relatively recent ancestor of
modern man, about 1 to 2
million years old.
The remains come from two
sites in Kenya and most have
just been unearthed in the past
year. Walker will be spending
part of the term of the grant doing further work there. After
the fossils have been sorted out
and organized, the project will
consist of "trying to get as
much information from the
fossils as we can."
This research will particularly
emphasize studies of how the
proportions of hominoids
change between the sexes and
with varying size, both between
related species and in individuals as they grow.
The idea is that some
biological constraints apply to
similar species of different
sizes, and result in changes in
form which accompany the
change in size.
Study of the differences in
proportions between males and
females fossils is important as
well, and can help researchers
both to learn about the social
structures of man's ancestors
and to determine whether
fossils belong to different
species, or merely different
sexes.
Ivey, founder and director of

Peabody's Electronic and Computer Music Studios and a coordinator of the conservatory's
composition department,
received a fellowship in music
composition.
According to Ivey, the Guggenheim awards in the creative
arts are not given for specific
proposals in the same way that
those in the physical sciences
are. Instead, they provide
assistance for practitioners in
these fields who are then free to
proceed as they see fit.
Ivey plans to do several different things during the year,
but the main project will be to
begin work on her second
opera. She says she has several
possible storylines in mind at
this point. She added that finding the right story and text is
a major part of the composition
of an opera—the text must provide dramatic themes which can
be emphasized by music and
these themes must be themes
which the composer is interested in emphasizing.
Ivey said also that the work
will be primarily performed by
live singers and instruments,
but may include some electronic sounds. Ivey has composed some pieces entirely for
conventional instruments, some
for instruments and synthesized sounds on tape, and some
which are entirely electronic.
She said she views electronic
sounds as "one part of the
composer's palette"—not all
pieces have flutes, not all pieces
use electronics.

These days you're going to get the
cheapest men's haircut at one of
those chain-cutteries and we find
nothing wrong with that. But we
prefer, if we're going to get our
hair cut at a moderate price, to
channel our money into a small
business, closely held and without a
lot of overhead for fancy "atmosphere," athertising, and corporate superstructure. So we go to
Hair Unlimited. This tiny studio,
tucked away in the basement of a
white-stucco apartment building,
certainly has low overhead, but
your hair looks great once you
climb back to street level. The proprietor, Ellen Gifford, has been
cutting for 12 years and has owned
this shop for more than half that
time. She has a steady, experienced
hand, and tells the best jokes we've
ever heard in the chair.

It's no secret the campus will look far
different in, say, five years. What is in
doubt is the extent to which those
changes will benefit students.
Obviously, students will benefit as
much as everyone else from the academic
improvements brought about by renovation. But an equally important question
is how much the social lives of students
will improve. Most of the construction
already planned (or already underway)
is for places such as Mergenthaler/Jenkins, Ames and a new Physics
and Astronomy building—places that
don't effect the non-academic lives of
students very much.
Even the changes slated for Gilman
Hall—the one significantly nonacademic building where renovations are
already in the works—are mainly general
improvements like lighting and heating
and moving the academic deans into the
building.
But in defending the recent tuition increase to the Student Council Wednesday, University President Steven Muller
brought up an idea we think would
benefit the average Hopkins student:
building a connection between Gilman
and Levering halls,
The proposal is far from novel. Such
a plan has been bouncing around for
years, although it has always been in that
eternal "very, very tentative" stage administrators love so dearly. The idea is
generally to use the area as a true student union, with things such as corn-

Whoa
To the Editor:
Whoa just a minute on calling my criticism of Gatsha
Buthelezi and Inkatha "deceplive" and a "half-truth" in
your editorial (4/18/86). It's
clear that you folks generally
like to attack all sides and occupy a safe middle ground—
thank goodness the LaRouchies
haven't taken up divestment
yet—bufyou needn't distort my
position.
That position, recorded in a
letter to the editor (4/11/86), is
simply that "It is for. .the attacks on anti-apartheid activists
that Buthelezi and Inkatha are
hated so much by so many
black South Africans.(See the
New York Times article of
March 31 where lnkatha is
described as "a fascist
organization" and "wholly in
league with the white
authorities.") The quotes in the
Times article came from a formal resolution passed by a large
broad-based coalition—the National Education Crisis
Committee--working on the
township school boycotts. To
make this clear, the Coalition
for a Free South Africa had
posted seventy copies of the full
Times article around campus
Iwo weeks ago. That fact, plus
the sentence preceding the
Times quotes, makes your case
that I was being deceptive a
very weak one.
There was no intention on
my part of attributing the unfavorable description of Inkatha to the Times reporter. If
anyone had that impression, I
am sorry. Any misunderstanding on this issue exists not
because we in the Coalition for
a Free South Africa haven't
done a lot of work trying to
educate the COM1111111ily on the
very real danger of Inkatha and
the so-called "Buthelezi option." If our concern makes us
appear extreme next to our
campus opponents, so be it.
Both Theo Nkone and myself
still stand behind our statement
that any objective observer of
apartheid must conclude that
Buthelezi is a stooge of
Pretoria.
Surely in your editorials you
have the capacity to assess the
evidence on this problem and
make a fair judgement, rather
than take statements out of
context in order basically just to
criticize both sides.

A Nobody
To the Editor:
Enough has been said about
student apathy. I just don't
want to hear it. The fact is,
most of the time we aren't even
given the chance to be nonapathetic. Take the recent class
elections. On April 15, being
the good Hopkins student that
I am, I went out there to vote,
right?
Wrong. They would not let
me vote. "I'm sorry, but only
those currently registered as
juniors can elect Senior Class
Officers," was more or less
what I was told. I tried to explain that I am not graduating
this year, even though I am
listed as a senior (I am actually
in the Class of '87, or so I
thought), yet to no avail.
"Well, it is not such a big
deal anyway" was the guy's approximate final statement.
Of course its not such a big
deal. IF insignificant, trivial
things like these arc not worth
the effort, then why bother going for the important matters?
Why get involved at all in
anything?
I just realized that this makes
me an orphan; they won't let
me into the junior class, and the
senior class is graduating. I
wonder about next year. I'll
probably go out to vote, and
they'll say, "Sorry, but you do
not seem to be registered as an
undergraduate, so you cannot
vote. By the way, didn't you
graduate last year?" Great, just
great! This year I'm an orphan,
next year I'll be a nobody.
Stefano Cazzaniga

Objectivist Club
To the Editor:
From reading letters that I
have seen in this newspaper and
elsewhere, and from other
things I have read and heard, I
have seen that there are probably a number of people at
Hopkins who are dissatisfied
with the philosophies which are
prevalent in our society and on
campus, and would welcome an
alternative. For those of you
who are interested, there is the
Johns Hopkins Objectivist
Club.
We are not a political
organization, like the Young
Democrats or the College
Republicans, but we meet to
discuss and debate any
issues—political, economic,
social,
intellectual,
philosophical— and we feel
that we can offer something
that no political group can—a
clear, consistent and rational
philosophy,
There are three principal and
parallel tenets to Objectivist
philosophy: Objective Reality,
the idea that the evidence that
our senses provide us with is the
real world around us, and that
there is no "other world"
which we cannot perceive; Rationality, the idea that man's
reason is his means of life, and
that no other ways for gaining
knowledge exist than by observing the world and drawing raIlonal conclusions; and Rational Self-Interest, the idea
that a man is his own responsibility, that the furtherance of

to the advancement of Objectivist philosophy and ideals. We
meet each Wednesday evening
at 7:30 p.m. in Conference
Room A beneath the Glass
Pavilion. Anyone who is interested in our ideas, or anyone
who disagrees and wishes to
discuss their differences, is encouraged to come.
Steve Jameson

Quanta Fitfit & Lega Tips?
Queen of Sheba
2126 Maryland Aye.
VISA, MC, AE. 547-1106
by Pamela Curt
Before hearing about Queen
of Sheba, I had not even known
restaurants that served authentic Ethiopian cuisine, so my
friends and I did not know
what to expect when we entered
the dimly lit dining room. Interesting music was playing,
and the ambience had a pleasant feel. The costumes the
waiters and waitresses wore
heightened the atmosphere.
We were seated immediately
and menus were brought promptly. We ordered the Honey Wine
(2.75), a sweet honey-flavored
white wine, which we sipped
while we chose from a wide
range of dishes. These included beef, lamb, chicken,
seafood, and vegetarian entrees. The menu described
Ethiopian food to have two
main ingredients: the first, Injera, is an unleavened sour
dough bread made of various
grains and has a crepe-like consistency. The second is a spiced
stew which acts as a base for the
meat or vegetable. Key Wat
contains a spicy red hot pepper
called berbere and spicy butter
known as Niter-Kibbeh. Alicha
contains Niter-Kibbeh, plus
tumeric, green peppers and
spices.

Two of us shared Queen
Sheba's dinner for two
($25.00), which included a
sampling of five of the main
dishes and homemade cottage
cheese and two vegetables,
which are served with all meals.
The dinner also included two
glasses of Queen Sheba's wine,
which was similar to the Honey
Wine. The dinner for four
($43.50) included even more.
My other friends chose Yatakilt
Kilikl ($5.50), fresh broccoli
and cauliflower simmered with
tomato, onion, and green pep- per, and Minchet Abish
($5.25), chopped top round
cooked with a combination of
seasonings and onions. Our
sampling of Doro Wat, Lega
Tibs, Quanta Fitfit, and Yebeg
Wat was overwhelming. The
spiciest were the Doro Wat,
chicken in berbere sauce, and
Kitfo, Ethiopian steak tartare.
The Lega Tibs, Ethiopian style
Shish-Kebob, and Quanta Fitfit, seasoned beef cubes mixed
with Injera, were my favorites.
The Yebeg Wat was a mild
lamb and berbere dish which
was also very pleasing. Our two
"vegetables were lentil bean dip
and delicately seasoned
tomatoes.
The food was brought in serving bowls on two giant silver
platters lined with lnjera. More
Injera was served on another
plate, and it became apparent
that we were to use the bread in

place of utensils. This proved to
be most challenging and very
fun. Its mild flavor helped to
balance the highly seasoned entrees. The homemade cottage
cheese was the best I had ever
tasted. It was impossible for us
to finish the enormous amount
of food which crowded the
table. For those interested in
ordering specific entrees instead
of the elaborate dinners listed
above, prices ranged from $5 to
$7. Salads ran from $1.75 to
$2.50. Only two appetizers were
listed, vegetable or meat Sambussa ($1.95, $2.25) which were
pastry shells filled with a spicy
hot filling, and Azifa ($2.95), a
cold lentil bean and herb dip.
Dessert was a choice of three
different cakes, Carrot, German Chocolate, and :Devil's
Food. At $2.50 per slice, the
small portion of dry German
Chocolate cake was a disappointment. The standard selection of beverages were available
as well as Ethiopian wines and
coffee.
My friends and I found
Queen of Sheba to be an inexpensive and pleasantly different
dining experience. Other than
having to wait a while for our
food, the service was excellent,
and the food well worth waiting
for. It is within walking
distance from campus and was
a nice change from the standard
fare in the area.

A Chance to
Strike Out a Dean
So you want to strike out
a dean? Or throw out Paul
Kadri at the plate?
Well, you may get your
chance next weekend, when
the Student Council, the
HOP and the Graduate
Representative Organization
co-sponsor the Hopkins
Grand Slam, a softball tournament to benefit the National Kidney Foundation of
Maryland.
"It's kind of a combined
effort," said co-chairman
Tim Fallon. He said he hopes
the tournament will raise
about $1000-$1500 for the
charity.
The money will be raised
through a $5-per-person fee.
For the fee, participants will
be ible to play two games
and-get a free T-shirt. Teams
will have to bring their own
balls, but other equipment
will be provided, Fallon said.
Individuals can also sign up,

he said.
Registration for the
tournament—which will be
played May 2-4--has already
begun, and will continue in
front of Levering Hall on
weekdays from 11 a.m. to 2
p.m. until Thursday. The $5
fee must be paid when
registering, Fallon said.
Teams—which will consist
of 10 members each—can be
formed by anyone. So far,
Fallon said, about 10 or 15
teams have committed to
playing, but he hopes to end
up with 30 to 40.
And if you've carried a
grudge all year—this may be
your chance. The Student
Council, the Student Activities Commission and Phi
Psi fraternity are among
groups that are already committed to playing.
If that isn't good enough
for you, Fallon said he hopes
the deans will form a team.

"We're Number

tie"

by Adam Warner
They couldn't have written a
better script. On a beautiful,
sunny, 80 degree day the Blue
Jays blew away third ranked
Maryland 14-9 in front of an
overflow Homecoming crowd.
And, thanks to Hobart's 16-13
victory over Syracuse, Hopkins
returned to where they belong,
the nation's top ranked team.
The Terps didn't go down
easy though. They broke ahead
early and were still tied in the
third quarter, but finally fell
victim to too much Hopkins
talent and too much Hopkins
depth.
Maryland has been winning
this year with a very simple
formula—ball control. Faceoff
man Todd Ensor won nearly 80
percent of his attempts going
into Saturday's game, thus giving his offense the ball a
disproportionate amount of
time. That was before he ran in
to Hopkins and Joe Rzempoluch.
The two met at midfield 27
times, and Rzempoluch won
somewhere between ten to thirteen of them, depending upon
whom you asked. This virtual
split took Maryland out of their
game, and was the key to the
Hopkins victory. "I've been
reading all week about Todd
Ensor," said coach Don Zimmerman,"but our boj,sure did
a great job today. l'be never
seen him so pumped up."
How did Rzempoluch get so
good, so fast? It seems that a
week's work with Dean of Admissions/former faceoff god
Jerry Schnydman turned the
sophomore from a better than
average specialist (58 percent
successful this year) into a
player who could disrupt a
whole team's offense.
The Jays simply have too
many guns to be beaten when

Hopkins vs. Navy
Where: Navy-Marine Corps Memorial Stadium
When: Saturday, 2:00 p.m.
Coverage: WJHU,88.1 FM, pre-game beginning at 1:45 p.m.
Preview:

A couple of weeks ago, Navy looked like the
upstart of '86 as they stormed out to an 8-0 start,
their best in twenty years. They've fallen back to
earth though, as they've since dropped consecutive
games to Maryland and Virginia without putting
up much of a fight.
Tomorrow is the Middies' season finale. They've
already locked in a playoff berth, but they're in a
somewhat precarious position. Navy is ranked
sixth, which means that should they drop just one
more spot, they will have to play an extra postseason game in this year's new format. Expect the
Jays to encounter a fired-up, hard checking team.
Navy's backbone is midfielder Glenn Miles, and
how well he plays will determine whether they can
pull off an upset In their eight wins Miles totaled
12 goals and 24 assists, but in their two losses he
had a combined total of 1 goal and 4 assists. He's
hardly a one-man team though, as the Middies have
some other excellent players such as freshman attack men Tom Hunzsche and Paul Basile and sophomore goalie Joe Dounely.
When the two schools met in '85, Hopkins blew
the Midshipmen out of the water, 23-10. It's gonna he a int tougher this time.

NEWS-LETTER/19

Lady Laxers Close With Win Over Swarthmore
On Saturday, April 19th,
Homecoming
Day, the
Hopkins' Lady Laxers ended
their 1986 official season in
grand style by defeating Swarthmore 12-11. It was a very
close game that could have
gone either way, but the lady
Laxers' unfailing determination
made the difference. After the
frustration of losing to both
Washington College and
Western Maryland by one goal,
the team worked together and
remained intense throughout
the game to pull out the victory.
Maggie Schmidt's five shots
from behind the goal and two
assists were an essential factor
in the Lady Jays' victory.
The Lady Jays started off
their season with scrimmages
against Ithaca College. Having
had the advantage of full field
play before these matches, the
team held their own. Their
24-10 victory against Notre
Dame in their first official game
of the season further boosted
their confidence. The tables
turned in the game against
UMBC, a top ranked division
II team. Although the Lady
Jays' outshot their opponent,
inexperience in goal and lack of
team speed became a factor in
the 11-7 loss.
The next games also took adHopkins'
vantage • of
weaknesses in goal and in
speed. The Hopkins scoring
percentage was one of the
highest its has ever been, yet the
other teams managed to score
ten goals per game. Despite a
20-13 loss to Haverford, the
Hopkins coaches were pleased

with the game. They felt it was
one of the best displays of offensive teamwork they have
seen at Hopkins in a long time.
There were seven assisted goals
in the game.
The turning point in the
season came when Hopkins
defeated Widener 9-7 having
been at a 4-5 deficit at halftime. The Jays continued their
winning ways by overpowering
Goucher 11-7. Goucher had
one of the best goalkeepers the
Ladies have come against this
year. Hood was next, Hopkins
glided through a 20-4 victory.
Beating a team like Swarthmore
was a great way to end the official game schedule. It was only a matter of time before
Hopkins would be the victor in
a one point match.
The Lady Jays will be going
to the Maryland State Tournamane this weekend at
Goucher. Hopefully they will
continue their winning streak
and return with the state title.

The players will also have the
opportunity to compete as individuals and be selected to one
of three Baltimore All-College
teams which then will play May
10-11 in the Southern District
Lacrosse Tournament at
Goucher College.
The junior varsity ended
their season in a tie against
Western Maryland. They were
down three goals in the last fifteen minutes of the game but
had an exciting comeback in the
last thirty seconds of the game.
The two other JV games were
6-8 and 6-12 losses to Goucher
and Gettysburg, respectively.
Skillful scoring from Soogie
Lee, Carleton Thomas, Katie
Swid, Patti Ordonez, Maggie
Schmidt, Joan Andres, Renya
Reed, and Sheryl Bedno provided for a strong JV team this
season.
The Varsity ended with a 5-6
season which with two forfeits
could be considered a 7-6.

wrapping up. The lacrosse

McGinn Shatters Blue Jay Mark
ly Laura Perlinn
The women's track team
cruised th:ough their last three
regular season meets and did
very well, considering the
number of runners on this
year's team. The talent is there,
but they don't have the depth
that is needed to win meets. In
their tri-meet versus Western
Maryland and York last Thursday in 41 degree rainy weather,
Hopkins had only the diehard
quintet of Molly Bardsley, Suzi
McGinn, Laura Perlinn, Lucy
Wilson and Lynne Wright, and
they still managed to outscore
both opponents in the running
events. The girls finished only

in second place overall though,
as they had nobody competing
in any of the six field events.
Suzi McGinn earned the most
points for the team, capturing
first place in the 200, 400, and
800 meter races and anchoring
the 44100 meter relay.
On Saturday, Mother Nature
must not have known that
Hopkins was running, because
the teams finally had a meet
when it wasn't cold and wet. Instead, it was sunny and 75
degrees, optimum running
conditions—except that the
meet was at Swarthmore.
Swarthmore has a "cinder"
track, made out of dirt and
sand with gravel thrown on top

The track team is ready to

Championships remain.
Coach Doherty believes
Hopkins' major strength is in
the 400 and 1600 m relays. Captain Larry Mermelstein has

anchor performances that

season. Tony Robinson, Tim
Rhyme, Greg Park and Matt

all
have
McCambridge

efforts.

McCambridge, Greg Park, Tim
Rhyme, Dave Connolly and
Paul Park have all had fine
400 m performances on relays.
The considerable depth in the
sprints has pleased Coach
Doherty.

Dalton had fine efforts flicking

however, was not satisfied as he
was prevented from working on
his tan.

Univsisity President Steven

presented to council, Hopkins
is shown as the 50th most expensive school among them.

position this year and for the
indefinite future," commented
Muller.

schools listed, Hopkins' tuition
was just $166 more than the,
average cost of the private institutions. "Out tuition does

any extra burdens on students
receiving financial aid since the
rise in University aid funds will
be slightly higher than the
change in tuition, according to

Chris Verica broke the tie
with Andrew Chun for senior
class president by seven votes in

Tuesday.

coming. I had an idea of who
got out to vote and I knew it
was going to be close, but it's
disappointing to lose by such a
close margin."
Verica, according to Paul
Kadri, who spoke to him by
telephone at his hospital in
Pennsylvania, "is really happy
to have won, and wants to give
thanks to those who have sup-

ported him and campaigned for
him."
Kadri said Verica is doing
well and is now on crutches,
which he hopes to trade for a
cane, and is hoping to attend
the FIJI semi-formal this
semester. He wants to "finish
his classes this summer, work
for the class, and sell Blue Jays
for Project Blue Jay," according to Kadri.
Chun concluded, "I didn't
really consider Chris to be my
opponent, I considered it to be
Paul. As he's shown in the past,
he's pretty tough to beat."

An undergraduate dormitory
resident became the victim of
an armed robbery and attempted
rape in her room on the morning of Sunday, April 20, according to campus security.
A preliminary investigation
of the incident suggests that the
assailant may have entered the
dormitory complex through
unlocked building and dormitory rooms, according to a
statement issued by Associate
Dean of Students Chris
Colombo.
Officer Edward Weichert of
campus security said, "We
found no evidence of forced entry, but that's not so unusual
since the building doors are
often left unlocked or propped
open."
According to Colombo's
statement, the victim described
her attacker as a black male in
his mid-twenties, approximately 5'9" and weighing 150 to 160
pounds. He was described as
having no facial hair and was
wearing a waist length tan
suede jacket, a white t-shirt,
blue jeans, and a tan leather
shoes.
According to Colombo and
Weichert, a review of dormitory security measures is currently underway. Weichert added though,"No committee has
been set up. We're just reviewing present measures."
He also said that security at
the dorms has not been increased
as a result of Sunday's incident.
According to Weichert, "Officers are detailed to the dormitories on a twenty-four hour
basis at night."
Both campus security and the
Baltimore City Police are currently investigating the incident. Anyone who may have
seen the assailant or a car
speeding away from the dorms
on Sunday morning is asked to
contact campus security.

week with the children in a oneto-one learning experience.

Four Hopkins Profs Win Guggenheim Awards
by Tom McNamara
Four faculty members at the
Johns Hopkins Institutions
have been presented Guggenheim Fellowship Awards for
1986. Jean Eichelberger Ivey,
Member of the Faculty in Composition and Director of the
Electronic Music Studio at the
Peabody Conservatory; Ronald
Paulson, William D. And
Robin Mayer Professor of the
Humanities and progessor of
English at the Homewood campus; William T. Rowe, associate professor of History,
Homewood; and Alan Walker,
professor of Cell Biology and
Anatomy at the School of
Medicine received the awards.
The fellowships provide funding for specific research projects proposed by the recipients
to the Guggenheim Foundationover a period of one year.
According to the Foundation, "The new Guggenheim
Fellows were appointed on the
basis of unusually distinguished achievement in the past and
exceptional promise for future
accomplishment." In 62 years,
over $116 million in fellowships
have been awarded.
Rowe received a grant to do
research in 18th-century
Chinese history over a period of
one year, spending the first six
months in Baltimore and the
last six in Taiwan. He described the research as primarily
biographical, covering th•
career of Ch'en Hung-mou,
who "was probably the most

STOP
END

influential
official
in
eighteenth-century China," and
served as governor or in the upper levels of administration of
at least twelve of the eighteen
Chinese provinces at different
times.
Ch'en was "an exemplar of
his particular style of government" who tried to understand
local communities and use existing local leaders and grotips
in governing and tried to rule
using preexisting forces, a
theory known as ching-shih,
translated as "statecraft."
Rowe said that part of the
research will be to learn in
detail how this administrator
applied his political ideas to
practical situations in different
areas—political ideas which
were very different from the
traditional Confucian concept
of leadership by example.
A seeming paradox is that
Ch'en was viewed later as both
an exponent of this pragmatic
school of thought, which as remained influential in China
ever since, and as "a great
moralist," according to Rowe.
Ch'en's work on the development of education stressing
cultural values, and his moral
treatises, as well as his letters
and writings on government
have been very influential.
According to Rowe, comparison of the theories and the
actual practices of this official
may help "to draw together the
sub-disciplines of intellectual
history and socio-political
history" of late imperial China.

Paulson's research will be on
"Memorial images in 18-th century English art and literature."
He wil study funerary
monuments, including statues
and architecture as well as written elements such as elegies and
epitaphs. In addition, he will
study images began in the 18th
century and the ways in which
they were broken up and
reconstructed and how people's
interest in these memorials
developed them over time.
Paulson will also be investigating the connections between the different art forms in
this area—he mentioned in his
book Book and Painting that,
"There is a real sense in which
English painting was a branch
of literature rather that art."
One reason for this was that
English literature was more
purely English than art was at
that time, and so was
sometimes more appealing to
English artists than were the
works of foreign painters.
Part of Paulson's research
will involve traveling in
England, in order to study
funerary monuments. The project will also include reading
and analysis of various
memorial writings, and traveling in England in order to study
these monuments. The project
will also include reading and
analyzing various memorial
writings.
Walker, at the medical
school, will be studying
"growth and sexual dimorphism in ancient hominoids."

Hominoids, he explained, include both apes and humans.
The study will center on two
groups of fossil remains, one of
ape-like animals approximately 18 million years old, and the
other of homo erectus, a
relatively recent ancestor of
modern man, about 1 to 2
million years old.
The remains come from two
sites in Kenya and most have
just been unearthed in the past
year. Walker will be spending
part of the term of the grant doing further work there. After
the fossils have been sorted out
and organized, the project will
consist of "trying to get as
much information from the
fossils as we can."
This research will particularly
emphasize studies of how the
proportions of hominoids
change between the sexes and
with varying size, both between
related species and in individuals as they grow.
The idea is that some
biological constraints apply to
similar species of different
sizes, and result in changes in
form which accompany the
change in size.
Study of the differences in
proportions between males and
females fossils is important as
well, and can help researchers
both to learn about the social
structures of man's ancestors
and to determine whether
fossils belong to different
species, or merely different
sexes.
Ivey, founder and director of

Peabody's Electronic and Computer Music Studios and a coordinator of the conservatory's
composition department,
received a fellowship in music
composition.
According to Ivey, the Guggenheim awards in the creative
arts are not given for specific
proposals in the same way that
those in the physical sciences
are. Instead, they provide
assistance for practitioners in
these fields who are then free to
proceed as they see fit.
Ivey plans to do several different things during the year,
but the main project will be to
begin work on her second
opera. She says she has several
possible storylines in mind at
this point. She added that finding the right story and text is
a major part of the composition
of an opera—the text must provide dramatic themes which can
be emphasized by music and
these themes must be themes
which the composer is interested in emphasizing.
Ivey said also that the work
will be primarily performed by
live singers and instruments,
but may include some electronic sounds. Ivey has composed some pieces entirely for
conventional instruments, some
for instruments and synthesized sounds on tape, and some
which are entirely electronic.
She said she views electronic
sounds as "one part of the
composer's palette"—not all
pieces have flutes, not all pieces
use electronics.

BEST MEN'S HAIRCUT
BALTIMORE CITY PAPER
These days you're going to get the
cheapest men's haircut at one of
those chain-cutteries and we find
nothing wrong with that. But we
prefer, if we're going to get our
hair cut at a moderate price, to
channel our money into a small
business, closely held and without a
lot of overhead for fancy "atmosphere," athertising, and corporate superstructure. So we go to
Hair Unlimited. This tiny studio,
tucked away in the basement of a
white-stucco apartment building,
certainly has low overhead, but
your hair looks great once you
climb back to street level. The proprietor, Ellen Gifford, has been
cutting for 12 years and has owned
this shop for more than half that
time. She has a steady, experienced
hand, and tells the best jokes we've
ever heard in the chair.

It's no secret the campus will look far
different in, say, five years. What is in
doubt is the extent to which those
changes will benefit students.
Obviously, students will benefit as
much as everyone else from the academic
improvements brought about by renovation. But an equally important question
is how much the social lives of students
will improve. Most of the construction
already planned (or already underway)
is for places such as Mergenthaler/Jenkins, Ames and a new Physics
and Astronomy building—places that
don't effect the non-academic lives of
students very much.
Even the changes slated for Gilman
Hall—the one significantly nonacademic building where renovations are
already in the works—are mainly general
improvements like lighting and heating
and moving the academic deans into the
building.
But in defending the recent tuition increase to the Student Council Wednesday, University President Steven Muller
brought up an idea we think would
benefit the average Hopkins student:
building a connection between Gilman
and Levering halls,
The proposal is far from novel. Such
a plan has been bouncing around for
years, although it has always been in that
eternal "very, very tentative" stage administrators love so dearly. The idea is
generally to use the area as a true student union, with things such as corn-

It's hardly news to note that this campus isn't exactly overflowing with places

Whoa
To the Editor:
Whoa just a minute on calling my criticism of Gatsha
Buthelezi and Inkatha "deceplive" and a "half-truth" in
your editorial (4/18/86). It's
clear that you folks generally
like to attack all sides and occupy a safe middle ground—
thank goodness the LaRouchies
haven't taken up divestment
yet—bufyou needn't distort my
position.
That position, recorded in a
letter to the editor (4/11/86), is
simply that "It is for. .the attacks on anti-apartheid activists
that Buthelezi and Inkatha are
hated so much by so many
black South Africans.(See the
New York Times article of
March 31 where lnkatha is
described as "a fascist
organization" and "wholly in
league with the white
authorities.") The quotes in the
Times article came from a formal resolution passed by a large
broad-based coalition—the National Education Crisis
Committee--working on the
township school boycotts. To
make this clear, the Coalition
for a Free South Africa had
posted seventy copies of the full
Times article around campus
Iwo weeks ago. That fact, plus
the sentence preceding the
Times quotes, makes your case
that I was being deceptive a
very weak one.
There was no intention on
my part of attributing the unfavorable description of Inkatha to the Times reporter. If
anyone had that impression, I
am sorry. Any misunderstanding on this issue exists not
because we in the Coalition for
a Free South Africa haven't
done a lot of work trying to
educate the COM1111111ily on the
very real danger of Inkatha and
the so-called "Buthelezi option." If our concern makes us
appear extreme next to our
campus opponents, so be it.
Both Theo Nkone and myself
still stand behind our statement
that any objective observer of
apartheid must conclude that
Buthelezi is a stooge of
Pretoria.
Surely in your editorials you
have the capacity to assess the
evidence on this problem and
make a fair judgement, rather
than take statements out of
context in order basically just to
criticize both sides.

A Nobody
To the Editor:
Enough has been said about
student apathy. I just don't
want to hear it. The fact is,
most of the time we aren't even
given the chance to be nonapathetic. Take the recent class
elections. On April 15, being
the good Hopkins student that
I am, I went out there to vote,
right?
Wrong. They would not let
me vote. "I'm sorry, but only
those currently registered as
juniors can elect Senior Class
Officers," was more or less
what I was told. I tried to explain that I am not graduating
this year, even though I am
listed as a senior (I am actually
in the Class of '87, or so I
thought), yet to no avail.
"Well, it is not such a big
deal anyway" was the guy's approximate final statement.
Of course its not such a big
deal. IF insignificant, trivial
things like these arc not worth
the effort, then why bother going for the important matters?
Why get involved at all in
anything?
I just realized that this makes
me an orphan; they won't let
me into the junior class, and the
senior class is graduating. I
wonder about next year. I'll
probably go out to vote, and
they'll say, "Sorry, but you do
not seem to be registered as an
undergraduate, so you cannot
vote. By the way, didn't you
graduate last year?" Great, just
great! This year I'm an orphan,
next year I'll be a nobody.
Stefano Cazzaniga

To the Editor:

As stated in the April 11
News-Letter, $440 of SAC

Objectivist Club
To the Editor:
From reading letters that I
have seen in this newspaper and
elsewhere, and from other
things I have read and heard, I
have seen that there are probably a number of people at
Hopkins who are dissatisfied
with the philosophies which are
prevalent in our society and on
campus, and would welcome an
alternative. For those of you
who are interested, there is the
Johns Hopkins Objectivist
Club.
We are not a political
organization, like the Young
Democrats or the College
Republicans, but we meet to
discuss and debate any
issues—political, economic,
social,
intellectual,
philosophical— and we feel
that we can offer something
that no political group can—a
clear, consistent and rational
philosophy,
There are three principal and
parallel tenets to Objectivist
philosophy: Objective Reality,
the idea that the evidence that
our senses provide us with is the
real world around us, and that
there is no "other world"
which we cannot perceive; Rationality, the idea that man's
reason is his means of life, and
that no other ways for gaining
knowledge exist than by observing the world and drawing raIlonal conclusions; and Rational Self-Interest, the idea
that a man is his own responsibility, that the furtherance of

to the advancement of Objectivist philosophy and ideals. We
meet each Wednesday evening
at 7:30 p.m. in Conference
Room A beneath the Glass
Pavilion. Anyone who is interested in our ideas, or anyone
who disagrees and wishes to
discuss their differences, is encouraged to come.
Steve Jameson

Quanta Fitfit & Lega Tips?
Queen of Sheba
2126 Maryland Aye.
VISA, MC, AE. 547-1106
by Pamela Curt
Before hearing about Queen
of Sheba, I had not even known
restaurants that served authentic Ethiopian cuisine, so my
friends and I did not know
what to expect when we entered
the dimly lit dining room. Interesting music was playing,
and the ambience had a pleasant feel. The costumes the
waiters and waitresses wore
heightened the atmosphere.
We were seated immediately
and menus were brought promptly. We ordered the Honey Wine
(2.75), a sweet honey-flavored
white wine, which we sipped
while we chose from a wide
range of dishes. These included beef, lamb, chicken,
seafood, and vegetarian entrees. The menu described
Ethiopian food to have two
main ingredients: the first, Injera, is an unleavened sour
dough bread made of various
grains and has a crepe-like consistency. The second is a spiced
stew which acts as a base for the
meat or vegetable. Key Wat
contains a spicy red hot pepper
called berbere and spicy butter
known as Niter-Kibbeh. Alicha
contains Niter-Kibbeh, plus
tumeric, green peppers and
spices.

Two of us shared Queen
Sheba's dinner for two
($25.00), which included a
sampling of five of the main
dishes and homemade cottage
cheese and two vegetables,
which are served with all meals.
The dinner also included two
glasses of Queen Sheba's wine,
which was similar to the Honey
Wine. The dinner for four
($43.50) included even more.
My other friends chose Yatakilt
Kilikl ($5.50), fresh broccoli
and cauliflower simmered with
tomato, onion, and green pep- per, and Minchet Abish
($5.25), chopped top round
cooked with a combination of
seasonings and onions. Our
sampling of Doro Wat, Lega
Tibs, Quanta Fitfit, and Yebeg
Wat was overwhelming. The
spiciest were the Doro Wat,
chicken in berbere sauce, and
Kitfo, Ethiopian steak tartare.
The Lega Tibs, Ethiopian style
Shish-Kebob, and Quanta Fitfit, seasoned beef cubes mixed
with Injera, were my favorites.
The Yebeg Wat was a mild
lamb and berbere dish which
was also very pleasing. Our two
"vegetables were lentil bean dip
and delicately seasoned
tomatoes.
The food was brought in serving bowls on two giant silver
platters lined with lnjera. More
Injera was served on another
plate, and it became apparent
that we were to use the bread in

place of utensils. This proved to
be most challenging and very
fun. Its mild flavor helped to
balance the highly seasoned entrees. The homemade cottage
cheese was the best I had ever
tasted. It was impossible for us
to finish the enormous amount
of food which crowded the
table. For those interested in
ordering specific entrees instead
of the elaborate dinners listed
above, prices ranged from $5 to
$7. Salads ran from $1.75 to
$2.50. Only two appetizers were
listed, vegetable or meat Sambussa ($1.95, $2.25) which were
pastry shells filled with a spicy
hot filling, and Azifa ($2.95), a
cold lentil bean and herb dip.
Dessert was a choice of three
different cakes, Carrot, German Chocolate, and :Devil's
Food. At $2.50 per slice, the
small portion of dry German
Chocolate cake was a disappointment. The standard selection of beverages were available
as well as Ethiopian wines and
coffee.
My friends and I found
Queen of Sheba to be an inexpensive and pleasantly different
dining experience. Other than
having to wait a while for our
food, the service was excellent,
and the food well worth waiting
for. It is within walking
distance from campus and was
a nice change from the standard
fare in the area.

A Chance to
Strike Out a Dean
So you want to strike out
a dean? Or throw out Paul
Kadri at the plate?
Well, you may get your
chance next weekend, when
the Student Council, the
HOP and the Graduate
Representative Organization
co-sponsor the Hopkins
Grand Slam, a softball tournament to benefit the National Kidney Foundation of
Maryland.
"It's kind of a combined
effort," said co-chairman
Tim Fallon. He said he hopes
the tournament will raise
about $1000-$1500 for the
charity.
The money will be raised
through a $5-per-person fee.
For the fee, participants will
be ible to play two games
and-get a free T-shirt. Teams
will have to bring their own
balls, but other equipment
will be provided, Fallon said.
Individuals can also sign up,

he said.
Registration for the
tournament—which will be
played May 2-4--has already
begun, and will continue in
front of Levering Hall on
weekdays from 11 a.m. to 2
p.m. until Thursday. The $5
fee must be paid when
registering, Fallon said.
Teams—which will consist
of 10 members each—can be
formed by anyone. So far,
Fallon said, about 10 or 15
teams have committed to
playing, but he hopes to end
up with 30 to 40.
And if you've carried a
grudge all year—this may be
your chance. The Student
Council, the Student Activities Commission and Phi
Psi fraternity are among
groups that are already committed to playing.
If that isn't good enough
for you, Fallon said he hopes
the deans will form a team.

by Adam Warner
They couldn't have written a
better script. On a beautiful,
sunny, 80 degree day the Blue
Jays blew away third ranked
Maryland 14-9 in front of an
overflow Homecoming crowd.
And, thanks to Hobart's 16-13
victory over Syracuse, Hopkins
returned to where they belong,
the nation's top ranked team.
The Terps didn't go down
easy though. They broke ahead
early and were still tied in the
third quarter, but finally fell
victim to too much Hopkins
talent and too much Hopkins
depth.
Maryland has been winning
this year with a very simple
formula—ball control. Faceoff
man Todd Ensor won nearly 80
percent of his attempts going
into Saturday's game, thus giving his offense the ball a
disproportionate amount of
time. That was before he ran in
to Hopkins and Joe Rzempoluch.
The two met at midfield 27
times, and Rzempoluch won
somewhere between ten to thirteen of them, depending upon
whom you asked. This virtual
split took Maryland out of their
game, and was the key to the
Hopkins victory. "I've been
reading all week about Todd
Ensor," said coach Don Zimmerman,"but our boj,sure did
a great job today. l'be never
seen him so pumped up."
How did Rzempoluch get so
good, so fast? It seems that a
week's work with Dean of Admissions/former faceoff god
Jerry Schnydman turned the
sophomore from a better than
average specialist (58 percent
successful this year) into a
player who could disrupt a
whole team's offense.
The Jays simply have too
many guns to be beaten when

Hopkins vs. Navy
Where: Navy-Marine Corps Memorial Stadium
When: Saturday, 2:00 p.m.
Coverage: WJHU,88.1 FM, pre-game beginning at 1:45 p.m.
Preview:

A couple of weeks ago, Navy looked like the
upstart of '86 as they stormed out to an 8-0 start,
their best in twenty years. They've fallen back to
earth though, as they've since dropped consecutive
games to Maryland and Virginia without putting
up much of a fight.
Tomorrow is the Middies' season finale. They've
already locked in a playoff berth, but they're in a
somewhat precarious position. Navy is ranked
sixth, which means that should they drop just one
more spot, they will have to play an extra postseason game in this year's new format. Expect the
Jays to encounter a fired-up, hard checking team.
Navy's backbone is midfielder Glenn Miles, and
how well he plays will determine whether they can
pull off an upset In their eight wins Miles totaled
12 goals and 24 assists, but in their two losses he
had a combined total of 1 goal and 4 assists. He's
hardly a one-man team though, as the Middies have
some other excellent players such as freshman attack men Tom Hunzsche and Paul Basile and sophomore goalie Joe Dounely.
When the two schools met in '85, Hopkins blew
the Midshipmen out of the water, 23-10. It's gonna he a int tougher this time.

NEWS-LETTER/19

Lady Laxers Close With Win Over Swarthmore
On Saturday, April 19th,
Homecoming
Day, the
Hopkins' Lady Laxers ended
their 1986 official season in
grand style by defeating Swarthmore 12-11. It was a very
close game that could have
gone either way, but the lady
Laxers' unfailing determination
made the difference. After the
frustration of losing to both
Washington College and
Western Maryland by one goal,
the team worked together and
remained intense throughout
the game to pull out the victory.
Maggie Schmidt's five shots
from behind the goal and two
assists were an essential factor
in the Lady Jays' victory.
The Lady Jays started off
their season with scrimmages
against Ithaca College. Having
had the advantage of full field
play before these matches, the
team held their own. Their
24-10 victory against Notre
Dame in their first official game
of the season further boosted
their confidence. The tables
turned in the game against
UMBC, a top ranked division
II team. Although the Lady
Jays' outshot their opponent,
inexperience in goal and lack of
team speed became a factor in
the 11-7 loss.
The next games also took adHopkins'
vantage • of
weaknesses in goal and in
speed. The Hopkins scoring
percentage was one of the
highest its has ever been, yet the
other teams managed to score
ten goals per game. Despite a
20-13 loss to Haverford, the
Hopkins coaches were pleased

with the game. They felt it was
one of the best displays of offensive teamwork they have
seen at Hopkins in a long time.
There were seven assisted goals
in the game.
The turning point in the
season came when Hopkins
defeated Widener 9-7 having
been at a 4-5 deficit at halftime. The Jays continued their
winning ways by overpowering
Goucher 11-7. Goucher had
one of the best goalkeepers the
Ladies have come against this
year. Hood was next, Hopkins
glided through a 20-4 victory.
Beating a team like Swarthmore
was a great way to end the official game schedule. It was only a matter of time before
Hopkins would be the victor in
a one point match.
The Lady Jays will be going
to the Maryland State Tournamane this weekend at
Goucher. Hopefully they will
continue their winning streak
and return with the state title.

The players will also have the
opportunity to compete as individuals and be selected to one
of three Baltimore All-College
teams which then will play May
10-11 in the Southern District
Lacrosse Tournament at
Goucher College.
The junior varsity ended
their season in a tie against
Western Maryland. They were
down three goals in the last fifteen minutes of the game but
had an exciting comeback in the
last thirty seconds of the game.
The two other JV games were
6-8 and 6-12 losses to Goucher
and Gettysburg, respectively.
Skillful scoring from Soogie
Lee, Carleton Thomas, Katie
Swid, Patti Ordonez, Maggie
Schmidt, Joan Andres, Renya
Reed, and Sheryl Bedno provided for a strong JV team this
season.
The Varsity ended with a 5-6
season which with two forfeits
could be considered a 7-6.

The women's track team
cruised th:ough their last three
regular season meets and did
very well, considering the
number of runners on this
year's team. The talent is there,
but they don't have the depth
that is needed to win meets. In
their tri-meet versus Western
Maryland and York last Thursday in 41 degree rainy weather,
Hopkins had only the diehard
quintet of Molly Bardsley, Suzi
McGinn, Laura Perlinn, Lucy
Wilson and Lynne Wright, and
they still managed to outscore
both opponents in the running
events. The girls finished only

in second place overall though,
as they had nobody competing
in any of the six field events.
Suzi McGinn earned the most
points for the team, capturing
first place in the 200, 400, and
800 meter races and anchoring
the 44100 meter relay.
On Saturday, Mother Nature
must not have known that
Hopkins was running, because
the teams finally had a meet
when it wasn't cold and wet. Instead, it was sunny and 75
degrees, optimum running
conditions—except that the
meet was at Swarthmore.

track, made out of dirt and
sand with gravel thrown on top
